title: Investigate typing progress job for DAST Python
description:
We've recently begun to add type hints to DAST's Python code. It'd be nice to have a CI job that lets us known if an MR is helping us progress towards our goal of total type hint coverage.

Ideally, it'd have this functionality:

1. Runs mypy on the feature branch
2. Accesses data from the latest mypy run on master (from an artifact?)
3. Calculates the percentage of untyped code on master to the percentage of untyped code on the feature branch
4. Adds a comment to the MR letting us know the difference in type hint coverage between the feature branch and master
    1. Also, includes the difference in total type hint errors between the feature branch and master (instead of or in addition to percentage?)

title: Publish API Fuzzing command line tools to package registry
description:
### Problem

The API Fuzzing command line tools are not currently published to a package registry. The tools are needed for a customer to perform advanced usage, and to facilitate creating HAR files.

### Proposal

Make the packages available via GitLab's package registry.

Publish to the staging registry in the `staging` `publish_stage` pipeline job. Publish to the production registry during the `production` `publish_prod` job.

* Production package registry: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/api-fuzzing/-/packages
* Staging package registry: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/api-fuzzing-src/-/packages

The following packages will be renamed and pushed:

 * gitlab-apifuzzing-ci - gl-apifuzzing-ci command line tool
   * Required by MVC
   * Provides basic ci integration, used in MVC to output report and log debug information about testing
 * gitlab-apifuzzing-api
   * Required by MVC
   * Python library used by other tools.
 * gitlab-apifuzzing-runner - gl-apifuzzing-runner command line tool
   * Required by MVC
   * Accepts an OpenAPI v2 or HAR for testing
 * gitlab-apifuzzing-recorder - gl-apifuzzing-recorder command line tool
   * Not required by MVC
   * Allows recording web traffic as HAR file
 * gitlab-apifuzzing-cli - gl-apifuzzing-cli command line tool
   * Not required by MVC
   * Allows reporting on active jobs, exporting reports, stopping running jobs

1. [x] Publish to staging registry in source project
1. [x] Publish to production registry via environments
1. [x] End-to-end test validating production publish worked
1. [x] Verify public permissions to production package registry

This issue does not include any documentation requirements.

title: Rename python packages and scripts
description:
### Problem

API Fuzzing has several command line tools written in Python that still use the Peach brand name. Before these tools can be published to the GitLab package repository the names must be compliant with GitLab naming practices.

### Proposal

Python packages will be prefixed with `gitlab-apifuzzing-` instead of `peachapisec-`. Command line tools will be prefixed with `gl-apifuzzing-` instead of `peach`.

The following Python packages will be updated:

 * peachapisec-api --> gitlab-apifuzzing-api
   * peachapisec --> gitlab.apifuzzing
 * peachapisec-ci --> gitlab-apifuzzing-ci
   * peachci --> gl-apifuzzing-ci
 * peachapisec-runner --> gitlab-apifuzzing-runner
   * peachrunner --> gl-apifuzzing-runner
 * peachapisec-cli --> gitlab-apifuzzing-cli
   * peachcli --> gl-apifuzzing-cli
 * peachapisec-recorder --> gitlab-apifuzzing-recorder
   * peachrecorder --> gl-apifuzzing-recorder

Tasks:

1. [x] Update the branding and output
1. [x] Update or add license file copyrights
1. [x] Remove code copyright statements
1. [x] Update setup.cfg for each
1. [x] Update each python package name
1. [x] Update the command names
1. [x] Update tests to reflect new names
1. [x] Update the build as needed
1. [x] Update `worker-entry` to use new binary name

title: Better support for connection errors with the Container registry
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

During a recent outage: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2381 it was brought up that in various places in the GitLab UI, we will show incorrect information.  If the API calls to GitLab fail, we do not indicate a problem with the Container Registry, but instead return nil values.  This is a serious problem as scripts may rely on the ability to find tags to determine if an object needs to be built.  This can lead to unnecessary rebuilds.  It would appear that our API may not be properly returning a valid response to the user when the Container Registry is suffering a problem.

See the original comment in that issue here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2381#note_375972108

### Steps to reproduce

1. Intentionally shutdown the Container Registry service
1. Perform various operations against the Container Registry:
    * Make an API call to find an image
    * Tell a CI job to pull an image

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The API will respond noting that the Docker image tag does not exist.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The API should return an error.

### Proposal 

Update the copy when an error due to the registry being unavailable occurs. This impacts both the API and the UI. 

#### User interface
`We are having trouble connecting to the Container Registry. Please try refreshing the page. 
If this error persists, please review the troubleshooting documentation.`

#### API
`We are having trouble connecting to the Container Registry. If this error persists, please review the troubleshooting documentation.`

title: Add codeowners to usage data
description:
## Problem

Usage of codeowners feature is not currently instrumented

## Proposal

Add codeowners to usage data, we are aiming to answer the following questions:

1. How many repositories contain a codeowners file?
  * What is the percentage repositories using codeowners?
  * What is the percentage of customers using codeowners (namespace for GitLab.com, instance for self-managed)
2. Out of the total number of codeowners files, how many of those files are making use of the sectional codeowners feature? (not sure if this one is doable)

## Further info

title: Mark merge request as "draft" with a single click
description:
# Make draft merge request feature discoverable

## Problem

Marking an MR as draft/wip is great to signal to others that the work in on-going and not ready for review, however, the feature has low discoverability and using is not intuitive unless you go into edit mode and read all the text on the page.

## Proposal

Update the multi-action dropdown button to offer the ability to "mark as draft" (dropdown would offer 3 total options, along with "close" and "report abuse")

| Expanded | On form |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/cd439c58e27cec42bfb00b2e05d40670/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/7f2550897e6af1f37d353c39e4da4f90/image.png) |

---
* state when MR is NOT in DRAFT mode:

```
Mark as draft
Close merge request
Report abuse
```

* state of button when MR is in DRAFT mode

```
Mark as ready
Close merge request
Report abuse
```

<details>
<summary>Original proposal</summary>

| Option 1 | Option 2 |
| ------ | ------ |
| Update the multi-action dropdown button to offer the ability to "mark as draft" (dropdown would offer 3 total options, along with "close" and "report abuse") | Offer a new button in the MR screen |
| ![image](/uploads/7f2550897e6af1f37d353c39e4da4f90/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/ac1f1d5e349e3e779066bc73a19f2c51/image.png) |

</details>

## Release Notes

Creating a merge request is a great way to share your contribution with others and get the conversation started. Even if the code is not ready to be merged. In order to signal to others that a contribution is not ready to be reviewed/merged, we can prefix the merge request title with `draft` (formerly known as `wip`). This is useful, however, it entails going into edit mode, navigating to the merge request title, and typing the required prefix.

To make it easier to use this feature, we have introduced the `Mark as draft` button to merge requests. With a single click, you can indicate your work is in progress and not ready to be merged/reviewed.

## UX Research
In the Category Maturity Testing for Code Review, the WIP feature for Merge Requests is not easily discoverable. The most common ways participants signaled the in-progress status of the MR was by 1) closing the MR or 2) applying a label. [Dovetail insight](https://dovetailapp.com/projects/ac5e32e9-616d-4ddd-a1bb-1eb49084fe4e/insights/present/7c0e73f6-f88f-4a49-ac0c-a31ed117fa4d)

title: Incorrect URL in environment and review app
description:
### Summary

If I use `CI_PAGES_URL` as the URL for a review app, the URL linked in the GitLab UI uses example.com as the domain rather than gitlab.io

### Steps to reproduce

The following CI config is sufficient:

```
pages:
  script:
    - echo $CI_PAGES_URL
    - mkdir public
    - echo $CI_PAGES_URL > public/index.html
  artifacts:
    paths:
      - public
  environment:
    name: review
    url: $CI_PAGES_URL
```

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/JackDunnNZ/

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

https://gitlab.com/JackDunnNZ/CI_PAGES_URL/-/merge_requests/1 is created with a review app using the configuration above.

After the pipeline succeeds, the "View App" link on the MR goes to http://jackdunnnz.example.com/ci_pages_url

In the environments page, the link to "Open Live Environment" also points to the same example.com URL.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The links should be http://jackdunnnz.gitlab.io/ci_pages_url

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Runner log:

https://gitlab.com/JackDunnNZ/CI_PAGES_URL/-/jobs/629563390

(note that here `CI_PAGES_URL` is printed with the correct domain in the context of `script`)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Cannot add more than one environment variable
description:
### Summary Cannot add multiple environment variables. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Go to settings >> CI/CD >> environment variables 1. Add a variable (success) 1. Add a 2nd variable 1. When clicking on the `Add variable` button, nothing happens ### Example Project (If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report) (If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version) ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Cannot add more than one variable ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? Able to add multiple variables ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![2020-07-08_11.00.49](/uploads/7c6f1b64b963d860209a3b079fe1b7a9/2020-07-08_11.00.49.gif) ### Output of checks (If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com) #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes (If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem)
